Link Mash (February 4, 2014)

Feb 4, 2014
1 minute read

The weekly Link Mash is a curated selection of tools, stories, and other links that I found during my travels on the web. All of my links can be found on my Pinboard; you can also find the Link Mash archives here.

  • Draft. I’ve tried no shortage of writing apps. This one brings a bunch of neat features to the table: collaborative editing, “tracked changes” mode, export to Evernote, Dropbox, etc. Not sure it’s a permanent addition to my toolkit, but we’ll give it a shot.
  • TabCloud for Chrome. I can’t believe I’ve gone as long as I have without this extension. It’s premise is simple: if you’ve got too many tabs open in Chrome, use this extension to save them into easy-to-access-later groups.
  • Dropbox-Uploader. I’ve experimented with a Raspberry Pi lately and want to get Dropbox files to it. This great set of Bash scripts does the trick.
  • How I Lost My $50,000 Twitter Username. Another fascinating read on Twitter-based identity hacking.
  • How the U.S. Almost Killed The Internet. I waffle between thinking that the NSA is evil and that its actions are necessary. This great piece from Wired gets into the weeds and lays out a case for both.
  • The Rise and Rise of Javascript. In my heavy-duty web development days, I remember thinking, “How has no one come up with an alternative to Javascript?” This article makes a great point: not only might that not happen, it might actually be a good thing.
  • Tweeting the Psalms: Book I. The Psalms represent some of the most poetic, most human passages in the Bible. I ran across this the other day: each Psalm described in under 140 characters.
Theme crafted with <3 by John Otander (@4lpine).
